newsitem.title: USA: In art, as in life, Fed seeks sustainable growth.
newsitem.headline: In art, as in life, Fed seeks sustainable growth.

text.p: The Federal Reserve is a many-faceted institution. Assisting in the maintenance of a sound U.S. economy, its employees examine growth indicators, study aspects of monetary policy and ponder bank regulation.
So who would have imagined that for 20 years, the Fed has also been building a small art collection?
A special exhibition celebrating "Twenty Years of Collecting by the Federal Reserve Board" is on view on New York's Upper East Side at Beacon Hill Fine Art gallery until the middle of September.
Another exhibition at the gallery, "Dollars & Cents, A Selection of Trompe l'Oeil by Major Painters of the Genre," also includes some work from the Fed's collection.
The impetus for the Fed's art collecting came from former Federal Reserve Board Chairman Arthur Burns, said Mary Anne Goley, the director of the Fed Board's Fine Arts Program.

"When Arthur Burns came over from the Council of Economic Advisors, there was a memorandum that had been sent around by (President) Nixon to cabinet members and departments, asking each department to do something for the arts," said Mary Anne Goley, director of the Fine Arts Program at the Fed. "When (Burns) came here to be Chairman, that memo was on his desk."
The Fed then hired Goley, an art historian and authority on American painter John White Alexander (1856-1915), to give the visual arts a role at the central bank.
"Burns would see what central banks had in other countries and he concluded that this central bank ought to have something," said Goley. "And we had nothing."
So the work began. After two decades, the Fed owns 220 pieces of art and it wants to sustain that growth.
In this respect at least, the bank has a conservative policy -- it doesn't buy art. Art is donated.
Goley's approach to collecting is accommodative.

"We collect American and international artists from the 19th century to the present," she said. "We're interested in everything. We are an institution with an international reach so we do have some works by foreign artists."
But it is also restrictive. "My restrictive policy is that I want good art," said Goley.
But the Fed collection does not restrict itself to monetary themes, though Goley would like some more examples of the money pictures popular in the late 19th century.
"But that's because they are part of a particular era of art history, not because the Fed conducts monetary policy," she said.
Because they are very difficult to conserve, the Fed eschews photography and watercolors.

And restrictiveness does come into play with regard to who can donate art. "We do not accept anything from anyone we regulate and we take a pro-active role in making sure that does not happen," said Goley. Some gifts come from the artists themselves or their estates, she added.

To prepare for the Fine Arts Program's important anniversary, a special committee chaired by former Federal Reserve Chairman G. William Miller "assumed an active role in identifying potential patrons for the Twentieth Anniversary," said Goley.

A few of the works on exhibit in New York are "Shower on Lake" by Eduard Jean Steichen (1879-1973), "Landscape, Albany" by James McDougal Hart (1828-1901), "Mrs. Daniels with Two Children" by John White Alexander (1856-1915), "Abstraction-Verte" by Jean Helion (1904-1987), "Trees, Hudson at Newburgh," by Leon Dabo (1868-1960) and "Study from the Locomotive Series, 1988" by Lawrence Gipe (b. 1962).
On Goley's wish list for future acquisitions are "more Trompe l'Oeil money pictures, some American impressionist pictures and some colonial portraiture."
Meanwhile, wouldn't you like to know which picture Fed Chairman Alan Greenspan chose to hang in his office?
"The Fed Chairman has a wonderful landscape by an American Hudson River painter named Alexander Lawrie, an 1867 landscape called 'Pleasant Valley, Essex, New York,'" Goley said.
